title: Penetrating Abdominal Trauma
diagnosis_topic: Stab wound with peritoneal violation and potential organ injury
setup_script: A 28-year-old man arrives to the emergency department after being stabbed in the left lower abdomen. He is alert but appears anxious. There is a single 2 cm stab wound just below the umbilicus with minimal external bleeding. He has no significant past medical history.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 22/min, Temp 37.2 C, SpO2 98% on RA.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs focused abdominal exam
dynamic_flow.reply: Soft abdomen with tenderness around the wound, no obvious peritonitis, mild distension.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about other injuries
dynamic_flow.reply: No chest wounds, no pelvic instability, extremities unremarkable.
Positive for free fluid in Morrison's pouch and pelvis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CBC and type and screen
If resident initiates two large-bore IV lines and begins crystalloid resuscitation
dynamic_flow.reply: BP improves slightly but tachycardia persists.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident calls for emergent exploratory laparotomy without delaying for CT
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient taken directly to OR; laparotomy reveals small bowel injury requiring resection and repair.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays operative management to obtain CT scan
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient becomes hypotensive, develops peritonitis and requires damage control surgery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inserts nasogastric tube and Foley catheter
dynamic_flow.reply: Gastric contents decompressed; urine output 40 mL/hr.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses need for tetanus prophylaxis and broad-spectrum antibiotics
If resident asks about penetrating abdominal trauma protocols
dynamic_flow.reply: Indications for OR include hemodynamic instability, peritonitis, evisceration or impalement; otherwise CT scanning for stable patients.
Manage open abdomen if damage control used, monitor for sepsis and ensure nutrition.

critical_decision_points: Rapid assessment and resuscitation of penetrating abdominal injury
Recognition of indications for emergent laparotomy vs. imaging
Avoiding delays that could worsen hemorrhage or contamination
Initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics and tetanus prophylaxis
Postoperative management including damage control considerations
